*[Bug 18871] New: Uninstalling older versions of 4.x.x removes file association with .Rdata*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18871>

            Bug ID: 18871
           Summary: Uninstalling older versions of 4.x.x removes file
                    association with .Rdata
           Product: R
           Version: R 4.4.x
          Hardware: Other
                OS: Other
            Status: UNCONFIRMED
          Severity: normal
          Priority: P5
         Component: Installation
          Assignee: <mailto:R-core@R-project.org|R-core@R-project.org>
          Reporter: <mailto:tomas.telensky@gmail.com|tomas.telensky@gmail.com>

I had several versions of R (Rgui) on my computer (4.x.x) on Windows 10. The
newest one 4.4.1 I kept, and uninstalled all older. But these errors occurred:

1. This uninstallation broke my default apps (file association) with the .Rdata
file! 

2. The default apps dialog in Windows 10 didn't offer to set "R" for .Rdata
file any more, even though the 4.4.1 is still officially installed!

To fix that, I had to manually fiddle with registry, as described here:
<https://superuser.com/questions/1854460/how-to-change-version-of-r-application-the-rdata-file-is-associated-to/1854461#1854461>

This shouldn't be needed! The installer should be fixed.

text:
*[Bug 18871] Uninstalling older versions of 4.x.x removes file association with .Rdata*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18871>

Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
             Status|UNCONFIRMED                 |CLOSED
         Resolution|---                         |WONTFIX

--- Comment #4 from Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) ---
(In reply to Tomas T. from comment #2)

> OMG why should reinstall be needed? Do you know how long it takes to install
> those 300+ packages?

As Peter wrote, uninstalling R doesn't uninstall packages. Your packages would
be normally installed in a directory like
"C:/Users/<username>/AppData/Local/R/win-library/4.4". If you uninstall R 4.4.1
and then install it again, that directory will not be affected, you will find
all your packages there after installation. And this directory will be used by
R 4.4.x (for all x), so possibly multiple installations of R.

> Clean installer should handle this correctly. There is definitely room for
> improvement.

How this works technically is that an R installer sets file associations on
installation and removes them on uninstallation. So, considering install and
uninstall of various versions of R: if the last operation was uninstall, there
would be no .Rdata association; if the last operation was install, .Rdata would
be associated to the R version installed in that last install operation.

This is not easy to change. And it is not easy to even say what would be
better. Someone might want to, at uninstall, to set the association to the
previously installed R (someone to previously installed from now, someone to
installed before the one being uninstalled). Someone else to the latest version
of R installed. Someone possibly to something else (e.g. take into account also
whether the installations are per-user or the whole system, possibly take into
account whether native or emulated on aarch64). The current implementation has
the advantage that it is simple, and has been around for long, so users got
used to it. Like the other options, it wouldn't make everyone happy, but at
least one wouldn't end up running an unexpected version of R (as the
association is deleted).

> PS: Unfortunatelly, manual modification of the registry is currently the
> only way to do it without having to reinstall the R version you intend to
> keep.

When the association is deleted on the uninstall of R operation, you can use
Windows explorer to navigate to the .Rdata file at hand, click open, navigate
to the version of R you want to use (possibly to Rgui,exe within that version),
and that would open your file as well as set the association. I've tested now
on my Windows 10 this still works.

But, yes, modifying the registry entry is also a valid solution and some might
prefer that.

In principle, if you ever again run into a similar problem to this one, I would
recommend you ask on R-help mailing list rather than the forum you used. I
believe you would get a helpful advice there within a day.

*[Bug 18855] parseLatex() makes several errors in parsing*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18855>

--- Comment #9 from Duncan Murdoch (<mailto:murdoch.duncan@gmail.com|murdoch.duncan@gmail.com>) ---
Yes, that's a known issue with \def and \let.  It should be documented here,
similar to this documentation in the parseLatex vignette in that package:

"One plain TeX version of these macros is `\def`.  It is
recognized and an attempt is made to handle it, but there's
some really arcane syntax possible with `\def`.  If you use
that, it probably won't be parsed properly.  Stick with
simple syntax like

    \def\bea{\begin{eqnarray*}}

and you should be okay.  This will likely be added to R 4.5.0,
with the same limitations."

(I forget whether this made it into the CRAN version of the package, or is only
in the devel version on Github.)

Both \def and \let have the same issues.  I'll submit a patch to the docs if
you want that.  I won't submit a patch to try to handle all of the possible
syntax variations.
